context: The Estonian adjective 'kehv' is a versatile word that can be used to describe something as bad, poor, inferior, wretched, or meager. It has several main uses: 1) to describe qualities and capabilities (physical or mental), moral character, things, phenomena, or conditions; 2) to mean scarce, insufficient, or inadequate when referring to harvests, income, skills, etc.; 3) to mean poor, destitute, or needy when describing people from humble backgrounds. The word can modify nouns in both singular and plural forms (kehv vs kehvad).
